member.name: T:JB.Collections.EnhancedBindingList`1

StackOverflow
post by
Simon Mourier
.

member.name: M:JB.Collections.EnhancedBindingList`1.Move(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves the item at the specified index to a new position in the list.
member.param: The index of the item to move.
The new index.

if set to true the will be adjusted, if required, depending on whether an index shift took place during the move due to the original position of the item. Basically if you move an item from a lower index position to a higher one, the index positions of all items with higher index positions than will be shifted upwards (logically by -1). Depending on whether the caller intends to move the item strictly or logically to the position, correction might be useful.

if set to true the will be adjusted, if required, depending on whether an index shift took place during the move due to the original position of the item. Basically if you move an item from a lower index position to a higher one, the index positions of all items with higher index positions than the ones will be shifted upwards (logically by -1). Depending on whether the caller intends to move the item strictly or logically to the position, correction might be useful.

member.summary: Moves the specified item to the new index position.
member.param: The item.
The new index.

if set to true the will be adjusted, if required, depending on whether an index shift took place during the move due to the original position of the item. Basically if you move an item from a lower index position to a higher one, the index positions of all items with higher index positions than the ones will be shifted upwards (logically by -1). Depending on whether the caller intends to move the item strictly or logically to the position, correction might be useful.

The new index.

if set to true the will be adjusted, if required, depending on whether an index shift took place during the move due to the original position of the item. Basically if you move an item from a lower index position to a higher one, the index positions of all items with higher index positions than will be shifted upwards (logically by -1). Depending on whether the caller intends to move the item strictly or logically to the position, correction might be useful.
